componenttext: Well, there is a hearing today that will be continuing to address the issue. So it is being discussed, it's being worked even with all of the other business that has been going on in Springfield around budget. So we, as I said, we got strong support, unanimous support out of the extended energy and public utilities committee in March, unanimous and there's theories about the house and the Senate this week to continue to discuss it. So we remain positive, cautious but positive that we'll be able to get something through in this session. If we don't, and it's a likelihood that we're not going to get a build and we have to address the long-term profitability of the units, and we'll decide that as we see the legislative session in.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your expected generation guidance for 2015 to 2017 in New England is 2x, 2x plus today versus what it was in the fourth quarter release. You haven't acquired any assets, so can you explain how you been able to double your expected generation in that marke
componenttext: Your expected generation guidance for 2015 to 2017 in New England is 2x, 2x plus today versus what it was in the fourth quarter release. You haven't acquired any assets, so can you explain how you been able to double your expected generation in that market and the flow through impact it's having on your expected gross margin, which looks like it's up marginally over the next 2 years but then down marginally in '17?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, it's Joe, and I'll speak to that. And you're right, you noticed that the our expected generation in New England in all years has increased appreciably, and as such the generation percentage hedged has declined with that increased output of generatio
componenttext: Greg, it's Joe, and I'll speak to that. And you're right, you noticed that the our expected generation in New England in all years has increased appreciably, and as such the generation percentage hedged has declined with that increased output of generation. Very simply, we have disclosed in Q4 '13 that we had worked with a fuel supplier to restructure a contract that we have. And if you remember back then, our generation dropped by about 15% net quarter-over-quarter at that time. That contract restructuring has been terminated, and it will be effective at the end of June this year and the contract itself will revert back to its original term and condition. It has 2 impacts: One, you're seeing the generation impact and the hedge percentage impact and the notification of the termination by the end of the first quarter this year. So really, you're seeing it flow through on an immediate basis. The gross margin impact was very minimal across the horizon and as such, just mechanically when you look at the hedge disclosure, the dollars of the termination of the contract restructuring, as well as the increased value, the generation outlook and the margin is all flowing through gross margin line, and it's very minimal. So really, it's a volume change that you see with little dollar impact.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So then what's the economic rationale for termination if it's more or less NTV neutral? Are these fuel contracts per gas plants that have optionality associated with price volatility, are they base load? Why would you terminate that contract if it wasn't
componenttext: So then what's the economic rationale for termination if it's more or less NTV neutral? Are these fuel contracts per gas plants that have optionality associated with price volatility, are they base load? Why would you terminate that contract if it wasn't increasing NTV appreciably?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't say too much due to the confidentiality of the nature of the agreement. But I will say is the contract termination was the right of the supplier to held that right. And from our perspective, as I said, do it impact economically was very muted. I c
componenttext: I can't say too much due to the confidentiality of the nature of the agreement. But I will say is the contract termination was the right of the supplier to held that right. And from our perspective, as I said, do it impact economically was very muted. I can't speak to the supplier's perspective on why they terminated, but it's related to the long-term supply arrangement that we have.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to focus on the CPE product, if you could. First, with regards to your expectations on future retirements, I'm curious, do you see the CPE product as proposed driving retirements as you go to 100% CPE market? Is that conceivable? And what kind
componenttext: So I wanted to focus on the CPE product, if you could. First, with regards to your expectations on future retirements, I'm curious, do you see the CPE product as proposed driving retirements as you go to 100% CPE market? Is that conceivable? And what kind of units? And then subsequently, obviously, with Supreme Court here waiting on the DR decision, how do you see that ultimately impacting the base in CP products  and, eventual option here? Doesn't appreciably impact CP, or is it more of an impact on the base option?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Julien, it's Joe. I think your first question around retirements, we don't see a material impact. I mean, I think, the rational is first and foremost, obviously, to improve the reliability on the system. And to do that, you need a couple. We can go about
componenttext: Julien, it's Joe. I think your first question around retirements, we don't see a material impact. I mean, I think, the rational is first and foremost, obviously, to improve the reliability on the system. And to do that, you need a couple. We can go about that in a couple of ways. One is the hardening of the units themselves which has costs associated with it. The second thing is to make sure you have few well on the price for these units and there's a cost to do that. When you look at the economics of all that, we don't believe there's going to be material impact to return. I will sit here and say though, given this structure that's been laid out if it is implemented, I would expect that you would see an increased risk premium effectively in the marketplace given the fact that the penalty structure is changing rightfully so to ensure reliability. But I don't think out right that there would be a material impact on the retirement side.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the management?
componenttext: And on the management?

componenttext: I guess, from the DR perspective, there's a lot of fluff around the rules. But sitting here looking at this auction, we would expect to see that the demand response activity will continue the way it has. And then as you see as rule changes sometime, if it is a change whether it becomes a host of retail products as opposed to wholesale product, we'll have to see how that plays out.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: As you know, we have an extensive business both on the solar, as well as wind renewables part of our business. And how we've improved the returns on that business over the last number of years has been through the extensive use of project financing as a m
componenttext: As you know, we have an extensive business both on the solar, as well as wind renewables part of our business. And how we've improved the returns on that business over the last number of years has been through the extensive use of project financing as a means of returning capital to the corporate conference to reinvest either in the growth of utilities or fund some of our other expansionary efforts around. As an example, the peaker that we're building a New England or the combined cycles we're building in Texas. Certainly, we do watch and we do evaluate and consider the potential impact of value that a yieldco could have in our assets from the perspective of yieldco's potential buyers of those assets or through the potential to create our own yieldco. And we continue to evaluate that within our project financing efforts. We have retained that option to be able to do that. I think one of the key elements to the successful strategy around the yieldco is having a significant and visible pipeline of assets that you can drop down. And we have, I think, a good amount of assets, we have some elements like our elegy facility that if we decide to pursue that, and we have a long-term optic agreement that would provide attracted revenues that could fit in the type of structure. But at this point, we don't have any plans to pursue such a structure and continue to have a wait-and-see approach.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. So more of a retain the business, build it out and then see down the line rather than monetize it?
componenttext: All right. So more of a retain the business, build it out and then see down the line rather than monetize it?

componenttext: Absolutely. So you'll see us continuing to deploy wind investments. We have our project that we're developing down in Texas, in [indiscernible]. You continue to see us work down the path on the LNG project to secure a longer term outtake. And you see us through our Constellation business, continue to pursue opportunities to grow the solar side of our business.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Neil, as you know, we have significant debt issuance forthcoming that will be used to finance at the holding company the PHI transaction that we would look to reach market once we have visibility around a successful path in Mary land. We continue to evalu
componenttext: Neil, as you know, we have significant debt issuance forthcoming that will be used to finance at the holding company the PHI transaction that we would look to reach market once we have visibility around a successful path in Mary land. We continue to evaluate the balance sheet capacity and the space that we have at that holding company. As you know, we've said we'll utilize that holding company as a potential vehicle to finance regulated growth. I think an important element of this is the interplay between the growing earnings mix of our utilities business relative to our merchant exposure on how the rating agencies perceive us. And so to the extent that the rating agencies continue to evolve and their thinking around the risk embedded in our business and see us as the less risky credit, I would say that's the biggest mover of balance sheet capacity. Obviously, some elements around, whether it's capacity performance, the Illinois Clean Energy Legislation that would be additive to the company's cash flow and earnings would also be helpful to our ability to add further leverage to the holding company.

So we project that towards the latter part of the decade into 2020 time frame, but will continue to evaluate that based off of rate case outcomes.
And Neil, it's not specific from a free cash flow standpoint, the utilities being able to not just from a payout ratio standpoint, but from a cash -- free cash flow funding standpoint. Chris's point  on the latter part of the decade is when that cash would be available to potentially consider growing the dividend.

componenttext: This is Bill Von Hoene. To conclude at the end of May, if consumably can be extended if the budget [indiscernible] continues, it's unlikely that the energy legislation would be considered during that period of time. There is a 6-day session, veto session in November and into early December, which requires a supermajority on and it goes that test during that period of time. So that would be the next time the legislation would convene after the conclusion of this regular session.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to focus again on Illinois. So it seems like you guys have bullish energy prices in Illinois, and that's why you're not hedging much of your portfolio. You're also bullish on the capacity prices, at least in PJM. You just have this spike in ca
componenttext: So I wanted to focus again on Illinois. So it seems like you guys have bullish energy prices in Illinois, and that's why you're not hedging much of your portfolio. You're also bullish on the capacity prices, at least in PJM. You just have this spike in capacity. So how do you sum that up? Because on the one hand, if capacity places rise, then you have less of a volatility in peak invest potentially lower heat rates. So how does it reconcile with your outlook on heat rates?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. This is Joe. I think that what I would say is, if we talk just about energy price in Northern Illinois for a minute using prices at the end of the quarter, we do still see heat rate expansion. We don't think the market is priced or the upsid
componenttext: Good morning. This is Joe. I think that what I would say is, if we talk just about energy price in Northern Illinois for a minute using prices at the end of the quarter, we do still see heat rate expansion. We don't think the market is priced or the upside really driven by changing dispatches stock. And if you think about 2 different timeframes like '16, '17, we probably see less upside than we do when you go out to the '18, '19 time period and it's probably the tune of $2 accordingly. Just as importantly, we also have a view that we think natural gas is underpriced at this point, which in addition to that would drive prices higher net-net because you would see a slight heat rate decline with the rising natural gas. But net-net, it would be a positive outcome. And your point is right that from a hedging perspective, we continue to remain behind our ratable hedging plan in the Midwest to the tune of about 10% in '16 and '17 approximately just given those use.

componenttext: Okay. And secondly, in ERCOT, you keep saying that you have a cost advantage for the new build, and you clearly do. But forward curves are showing empty spot spreads of $15, $16. componenttext: Angie, it's Ken. Continue to be comfortable with our investments in these plans. Because as Chris said, the cost advantage, the technology advantage, meaning the heat rate efficiencies and the responsiveness of this plant, we've seen spark spread bound around a lot in ERCOT, the lack of volatility recently has driven down. Our long-term fundamental views are -- what I would say conservative, and we're still confident in the investment, very confident actually.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Bob Von Hoene. The RSAA contract was approved by FERC effective April 1 but with 2 adjustments being required in the contract, which has set back and a compliance filing will be made by Gane to reflect that and there will be a process by which the
componenttext: This is Bob Von Hoene. The RSAA contract was approved by FERC effective April 1 but with 2 adjustments being required in the contract, which has set back and a compliance filing will be made by Gane to reflect that and there will be a process by which the contract itself will be evaluated and potentially settled through a FERC procedure. So that is going to go forward for probably the balance of the year based upon precedents and other circumstances. Although the ability to collect on a cost-save base rate is effective now. The point is exercisable by EDM January 1, 2016, we do not know and that is what would happen in connection with that with regard to for the potential extension of the RSSA agreement, it's predicated on the period of time that's necessary for the New York system to find alternative ways to deliver the same reliability that Gane currently, is required to deliver. So we would not anticipate in the absence of the failure of the New York system to do so that there could be any basis of the extension of the agreement.

componenttext: There has been attention, not surprisingly, to the MISO auction in connection with the deliberations. And I think it's relevant in the mind of number of legislators. From our standpoint, however, it has virtually no impact on the health of our plans, the Clinton plans, which was a price taker in the auction and which had sold in advance, significant portion of the power, the benefit of the auction result is only about $13 million, so that's far shorter what would be necessary. It doesn't have yet the need for the Low Carbon Portfolio Standard for that plan or elsewhere.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: I wanted to clarify. I may have missed this, I think you were mentioning that on the forward prices was this fundamental view. If I heard you right, you said, you said Midwest was probably about $2 lower than what the fundamental view would be. I want to confirm that. And what's your thinking on Mid-Atlantic or PJM right now, forward versus fundamental?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, what I said was -- this is Joe. What I said was there's 2 components to our view. The first is just fundamentally we still expect to see heat rating expansion in Northern Illinois across the time horizon. So if you look at calendar '16, '17 and beyon
componenttext: Yes, what I said was -- this is Joe. What I said was there's 2 components to our view. The first is just fundamentally we still expect to see heat rating expansion in Northern Illinois across the time horizon. So if you look at calendar '16, '17 and beyond, we would expect to see heat rate expansion and that's probably in that $1 to $2 range. But additionally, we see gas price upside, which we think would also increase the power price beyond that upside. So that would effectively raise the heat rates as well and or effectively raise the power price as well. Suited to components in our view, and as such, we're behind the ratable plan in '16 and '17 from a hedging perspective to the tune of approximately 10%. And it's important to note that there are there's some seasonality associated with us in our hedging profile within the given year reflects that meaning. We see time buckets that are more valuable relative to the market and others. On the West Coast side, we see that heat rates and power prices are generally in line with our fundamental forecast, and we don't see why this was opportunity. But again, there's seasonality associated with that and our hedging profile takes that into account.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And Joe, one other thing. On the retail side, a quick update on the competitive environment, the $2 to $4 margin that we've historically been benchmarking just to give us a sense of where we are as new contracts are rolling in?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, in general, our load business has done very well whether we're talking about our retail book of business on the commercial industrial side or our polar procurement business on the wholesale side. After the polar vortex last year, we saw, I'd
componenttext: Yes, I think, in general, our load business has done very well whether we're talking about our retail book of business on the commercial industrial side or our polar procurement business on the wholesale side. After the polar vortex last year, we saw, I'd say, folks maybe pricing the risk more prudently from our perspective as it relates to managing a retail contract, that's one element of it. And then from a margin perspective using that $2 to $4 benchmark way out there, we're well in line within in the range of that $2 to $4 where we're sitting here 1.5 years ago, we were struggling to be even at the low end of that range. So we've seen improvement across-the-board, both from a risk pricing perspective and a margin improvement perspective in our load business, both wholesale and retail.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's couple answers to that question and I think the most important one is, we're seeing the changeover in the generation stack that we expected to see retirements and low gas prices. And you've seen the heat rate expansion that we've been
componenttext: Yes, I think there's couple answers to that question and I think the most important one is, we're seeing the changeover in the generation stack that we expected to see retirements and low gas prices. And you've seen the heat rate expansion that we've been talking about for some time. I think in addition to that, I think what you're going to see going forward, is increased volatility in both upside volatility and downside volatility. And I think that has an impact on load volume contracts because you need to make sure that, that they're priced accordingly. So we've got the benefit of what we call it lower load serving cost in the first quarter and they've come down on a mark-to-market basis for the balance of the year. But our expectation is given that market volatility, we expect to see that would pass through to continuing to see appropriate risk premiums in our load serving business and appropriate margins.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to circle back a little bit on PJM. We keep seeing a lot of announcements or people attempting to get new combined cycles build. We've, obviously, had a lot clear over the last few years. Gas base is still is pretty low, meaning still pretty w
componenttext: I just want to circle back a little bit on PJM. We keep seeing a lot of announcements or people attempting to get new combined cycles build. We've, obviously, had a lot clear over the last few years. Gas base is still is pretty low, meaning still pretty wide in parts of PJM relative to where Henry Hub is, where Pepco is. Just curious, kind of multi-year thoughts about whether a lot of actually do get build meaning, or do a lot just kind of disappeared by the wayside? And what this means not only for, I don't know, your view of are we kind of new build economics and PJM is a concept of building merchant combined cycle and PJM make sense to you here. Just kind of broader thinking about gas plan economics on that market.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's a couple of questions there. Let me try to tick them off one by one. I think the first one is as it relates to the turn over in the dispatch stack, I think it's clear that we're going to see retirements of generation assets. In our fundamental mod
componenttext: There's a couple of questions there. Let me try to tick them off one by one. I think the first one is as it relates to the turn over in the dispatch stack, I think it's clear that we're going to see retirements of generation assets. In our fundamental modeling, we have an ad add back of an appreciable number of gas-fired generators in PJM with most of them I'd say on the Eastern side of PJM because that's where the economics are more favorable toward territory like [indiscernible], for example. You're talking about a long-term investment asset with a build of a combined cycle plant, and you're looking at a market that spark spreads that make shorter data time horizon. In PJM, like some of the other markets, the capacity price comes into play as well and it's part of the equation. But, clearly, we don't see new build economics  work on the Western side of PJM. On the Eastern side of PJM, it's a much more marginal exercise. I think where spark spreads are, with capacity prices that you used last year as a benchmark, for example, I think you can say that's a marginal calculation. There was some talk if you go back a year ago that people are going to be able to lock in gas contracts for 20 years well under Henry Hub, at M3 gas or that land of gas. I would tell you I don't think that's going to be the case so there's an element of making sure that you understand what the dynamics or the cost of production are as well. But I think net-net, fundamentally, what we see is a turnover of stack, our fundamental forecast reflects that. So we have an appreciable add back of combined cycle plant and when we take that all into account, as I said, previously, we still see upside to the heat rate at NiHub, and we're generally in line with where the market heat rate is at West hub.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Britney, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Quarter 1 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Francis Idehen, you may begin your confer
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Britney, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Quarter 1 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Francis Idehen, you may begin your conference.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Britney. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Offi
componenttext:
Thank you, Britney. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. 
Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Officer. They are joined by other members of Exelon's senior management team, who will be available to answer your questions following our prepared remarks. 
The earnings release -- we issued our earnings release this morning along with the presentation, each of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. The earnings release and other matters which we discuss during today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in today's material, comments made during this call and the Risk Factors section of the 10-K which we filed in February, as well as in the earnings release and the 10-Q which we expect to file later today. Please refer to the 10-K, today's 8-K and 10-Q and Exelon's other filings for a discussion of factors that may cause the results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations. 
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for a reconciliation between non-GAAP measures to the nearest equivalent GAAP measures. We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Francis, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call. Before I go into the prepared remarks, I want to first start by addressing the situation in Baltimore. As a company with a significant presence in Baltimore, we're monitoring t
componenttext:
Thank you, Francis, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call. Before I go into the prepared remarks, I want to first start by addressing the situation in Baltimore. 
As a company with a significant presence in Baltimore, we're monitoring the unrest with great concern. As you know, Maryland's governor, Larry Hogan, has declared a state of an emergency and Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake has declared a city-wide curfew into next week. We join the rest of the business community in recognizing the issues that Baltimore is dealing with and needs to address, so this great city can -- this great city can heal itself and get back on to economic growth for all. Moving on to the quarter, I'm very pleased with our financial performance. We delivered earnings of $0.71 per share, surpassing our guidance range of $0.60 to $0.70, and Jack is going to describe our performance in greater detail. 
I would like to focus my remarks on our priorities in how we are strategically pursuing value for customers and shareholders. We continue to operate in a challenging market environment, particularly on the generation side of our business. But our gentle load match strategy continues to create value, as seen in the first quarter hedge disclosure. 
Our advocacy efforts are focused on creating our channels to capture value for our communities and customers we serve and for our shareholders. I'll touch on those directly. 
In our regulated business, we are redefining the role of the utility of the future in part by making needed infrastructure investments to marginalize the grid. Over the next 5 years, our LRP has $16 billion of capital that will create approximately 6% CAGR with another potential $7 billion at PHI. 
Installing smart meter technology to enable customers to make informed choices about their energy consumption and promoting energy efficiency investments and innovation in resilient technologies at our utilities is a way that is progressive and equitable across all customer types. You can see this reflected in the energy plan for Illinois' future bill that we recently proposed through ComEd in Illinois. 
With these efforts, we are bringing improvements to the lives of the customers in a way that creates value for the company. 
Our Merchant business face challenges, primarily due to policies and market design shortcomings that have failed to fairly value the benefits of nuclear. 
As a result, we focused our advocacy efforts on ensuring reliable environmental and economic benefits of nuclear power are not taken for granted and that these plants are operated on a level playing field. 
In Illinois, we are working with state legislatures and the Low Carbon Portfolio Standard that values each of these benefits. The bill unanimously was approved by the Center of Energy panel and the Public Utilities Committee and will now go to the Senate floor. We hope the same will happen in the house and that the bill will be approved within this legislative session. 
From a reliability perspective, we are pleased that FERC has graded the waiver to allow PJM to delay the capacity auction in order to further review PJM's CP proposal. 
It is clear from this transaction that FERC appreciates that the old drills are not sufficient to ensure reliability and the changes must be made. We look forward to a positive outcome. 
We continue to work through the process of finalizing a contract with RG&E for our Ginna facility. 
As these events play out, we continue to do our best, operating the plans and utilities at high levels of proficiency, hedging our generation output through strong portfolio management while we expand our footprint and our profits in retail power and gas operations. 
As you can see, we are doing things in both sides of our business. We're tapping into multiple channels to create upside and drive value for our customers and for our investors. This leads me to our proposed merger with PHI. 
As you know, we've obtained regulatory approval from FERC Virginia and New Jersey. We've reached a global settlement in Delaware that is pending a commission approval. That leaves Maryland and the District of Columbia. 
In Maryland, we've reached a partial settlement with several critical parties that has been presented to -- we presented that settlement to the Maryland Public Service Commission and expect a decision from them on May 15. 
In the District, we've completed our evidentiary hearings, and we're now filing briefs and the Commission will commence its deliberations. 
We have said from the beginning that this merger and the commitments we have made clearly demonstrate this merger is in the public interest and should be approved by the regulatory commissions. 
While there is no guarantee that the Public Service Commission will approve the proposal and there is no guarantee they will not impose conditions that would frustrate the transaction, we believe that the settlement and commitments that we have made in the proceeding more than meet the statutory requirements for the merger approval, and we look forward to orders approving the merger. We expect the merger to close late in the second quarter or in the third. 
In summary, we're creating value today while actively pursuing public policy changes that recognize the benefits provided by our clean, reliable assets, and we're working on all those fronts. 
I'll now turn it over to Jack, who will cover the financial performance for the quarter.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. We had a strong first quarter to start the year. My remarks will cover our financial results for the quarter, second quarter guidance range and update our hedge disclosures and cash outlook. I'll start on Sl
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. We had a strong first quarter to start the year. My remarks will cover our financial results for the quarter, second quarter guidance range and update our hedge disclosures and cash outlook. 
I'll start on Slide 4. Starting with our first quarter results on Slide 4. Exelon exceeded our guidance range and delivered earnings of $0.71 per share. 
At Exelon Generation, once again, we realized the benefits of our generation to load matching strategy. 
Quarter-after-quarter, this strategy is paying dividends in a broad array of market conditions. 
During the first quarter, despite experiencing lower power prices during the same period of 2014, we benefited from a lower cost to serve customers. 
We are realizing strong margins in our load business from contracts we executed last year after the polar vortex. 
In addition, our gas business performed above our expectations during the quarter due to favorable weather. 
While our nuclear plants performed better than they did at this time last year, we did have some nuclear outages that negatively impacted our quarterly earnings by approximately $0.04 relative to plan. 
That being said, we continue to push our plans to perform at our standard highest levels of performance. 
Our portfolio management team performed strongly and was able to more than offset these losses. On balance, generation earned $0.35 per share during the quarter. 
Exelon's utilities delivered combined earnings of $0.39 per share, an $0.08 increase over the first quarter of last year. 
Although we did not see a repeat of the polar vortex of 2014 with sustained extreme cold and wind chills, we faced a very cold winter with heating degree days 14% to 19% above normal in ComEd's and PECO's service territories. 
In fact, it was colder in Philadelphia this winter than the previous winter. 
Cold weather, a lack of severe storms and increased distribution rates at BGE drove utility results this quarter. More detail on quarter-over-quarter drivers of the utilities can be found in the appendix on Slide 16. 
For the second quarter, we are providing guidance of $0.45 per share to $0.55 per share. This compares with our realized earnings of $0.51 per share in the second quarter of 2014. We are reaffirming our full year guidance of $2.25 to $2.55 per share. 
Since our last call, both PECO and ComEd have filed rate cases this year. On March 27, PECO filed an electric distribution rate case with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission, requesting a $190 million revenue increase and a 10.95% return on equity. This is PECO's first rate case filing since 2010 and the first time filing based on a fully projected future test year. 
In addition, if the PAPUC approves the new system 2020 plan, an additional $275 million will be spent during the next 5 years to install advanced equipment and reinforce the local electric system, making it more weather resistant and less vulnerable to storm damage. 
We expect the PAPUC to rule by the end of the year on the rate case and system 2020 plan with new rates going into effect in January of 2016. 
On April 15, ComEd filed the general formula rate filing with the Illinois Commerce Commission. ComEd requested a revenue decrease of $50 million. This reduction is a result of a continued focus on cost management and operational efficiencies that are being realized from a stronger, more reliable grid with fewer outages. 
EIMA and the Smart Grid investments are working. 
Since 2012, there have been more than 3.3 million avoided customer interruptions, including 1.2 million in 2014 due largely to increased investments in distribution automation or digital smart switches that automatically route power around problem areas.  Outage avoidance has saved customers an estimated $175 million. More detail on each of these rate cases can be found in the appendix on Slides 20 through 22. 
I will now turn to our first quarter gross margin update on Slide 5. During the quarter, we saw a drop in natural gas prices while power prices were steady and heat rates expanded further. The market is finally incorporating the change in the generation stack due to coal retirements, as evidenced by the heat rates seen today. Approximately 10 gigawatts of coal plants that PJM have or will retire this year with the majority of retirements occurring in April and May. 
We hedged close to a ratable amount during the quarter in both the mid-Atlantic and Midwest regions. At the end of the quarter for 2016 and 2017, we remain considerably behind ratable in the Midwest where we continue to see upside. 
Total gross margin is unchanged or relatively unchanged across 2015 through 2017 from our fourth quarter disclosures. 
As I mentioned, Constellation had a good quarter and executed $200 million in power new business and $100 million in non-power new business. 
In addition, we raised our power new business target by $100 million because we have line of sight for continued success in the balance of the year. 
This increase was offset by our nuclear outages resulting in a net $50 million improvement in 2015 total gross margins. 
Slide 6 provides an update on our cash flow expectations for this year. Projected cash from operations is $6.7 billion.  I'd like to point out that we've increased our CapEx projections at ComEd by $200 million. And finalizing the investment plan for 2015, ComEd identified incremental opportunity to invest in infrastructure including grid resiliency and security, storm hardening and Smart Grids.  These investments will continue to improve the reliability of ComEd's system. 
As a reminder, the appendix include several schedules that will help you in your modeling efforts. Thank you. 
And we'll now open the line for questions.

componenttext: We've been hearing or I've been hearing a lot of concerns about the Pepco acquisition and probably some of Maryland comments, both the MEA and the governor's office. Can you just kind of share your thoughts on how you guys address maybe the market power considerations or issues that are raised and how you guys move past that to get this deal done?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There are some that have mentioned a loss of competition and as all know, Pepco Maryland and BGE do not compete. They each will be standalone in the future. They are now rate cases and will be decided by the Public Utility Commission in Maryland. We
componenttext: Yes. There are some that have mentioned a loss of competition and as all know, Pepco Maryland and BGE do not compete. They each will be standalone in the future. They are now rate cases and will be decided by the Public Utility Commission in Maryland. We work at the will of the commission. Now the benefits that we show by bringing PHI into the Exelon utilities with best practice, sharing, being able to leverage procurement and the commitments that we made, we think, meet the test to the best -- for the benefit of the consumer. And so the governor has not taken that position. The governor stayed neutral since he said he's come into this late in the process, so there was rumors that he was against it. That was clarified with the letter that he sent to the commission saying he has faith in the commission that they'll do the right thing and he's neither for or against, he's neutral on it, and that's the support that we've gotten from Montgomery County and Prince George's County is significant. Those were the major customer bases, the majority of the Marilyn customers are and we have strong support from both counties.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And I guess, just to play devil's advocate but if Pepco were not to sell, you guys have funded the equity component of that transaction well in advance. How would you guys use that capital if you ended up having it back to deploy in a different direction?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Jack. Obviously, we don't anticipate that to happen. We anticipate getting a successful outcome here to the extend that the terms of approval were onerous or we were rejected outright, we would look to cash settle the equity, that forward that w
componenttext: Dan, it's Jack. Obviously, we don't anticipate that to happen. We anticipate getting a successful outcome here to the extend that the terms of approval were onerous or we were rejected outright, we would look to cash settle the equity, that forward that we have issued, and we would utilize the -- we would look to utilize the capital raise from the convertibles to either fund growth at the business or return value to shareholders through other means.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, just one last question on prioritization of capital. Obviously the ERCOT, CCGTs are out there but there's been more conversation about with respect to the LNG project that you guys are an early the investor in as well as these stories a
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, just one last question on prioritization of capital. Obviously the ERCOT, CCGTs are out there but there's been more conversation about with respect to the LNG project that you guys are an early the investor in as well as these stories about the U.K. office. Can you just kind of clarify how you guys are prioritizing those capitals and maybe addressing any of the issues that might be around what we've been hearing in the media?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you can see, based off of our capital spend, our highest priority is in the regulated investments. We're making, as I said, $16 billion of investment over the next 5 years with another potential $7 billion with Pepco being PHI coming in. So that i
componenttext: Yes. As you can see, based off of our capital spend, our highest priority is in the regulated investments. We're making, as I said, $16 billion of investment over the next 5 years with another potential $7 billion with Pepco being PHI coming in. So that is we see is a good solid investment needed for the infrastructure for the customers and benefits the shareholders. The CCGTs in Texas are still a very good investment, very positive NPV. It continues to match our generation to load strategy as we continue to grow that load book in Texas in ERCOT. We said at the beginning, we're getting these at a very good term. They're under $700 a kW on our brownfield site where we'll have expense advantages of combining them with our existing facilities. And the nature of those plants, the efficiency and the flexibility of them, they'll dispatch well in that ERCOT market. So that's still a positive investment. Enova is a good, strong option. We're the 5th largest in handling merchant gas. We have core competencies around our gas portfolio and continuing to grow up the gas business is a logical move, we believe. But the nature of that project is contracted, it would be a contracted, long-term type arrangement that derisks it significantly. If we are successful in obtaining contracts and permits, then we would make the investment to continue to develop out our gas business. So that's the strategy around the utility, the strategy around competitive electric and gas, continue to be the primary. The story in the U.K. is not an equity story at all. Exelon nuclear partners has been invited into the bidding process to be the operator on a couple projects potentially in the U.K. We have a very small office that we rent month-to-month that those folks are working out of. Part of the process of doing that is understanding more, the U.K. market. So there's been some due diligence around that but we have no plans right now on becoming an equity owner in the U.K. at this point, but those are -- there was a clarification needed to be made.

componenttext: Well, there's a hearing today that will be continuing to address the issue. So it is being discussed, it's being worked even with all of the other business that has been going on in Springfield around budget. So we've -- as I said, we got strong support, unanimous support out of the extended energy and Public Utilities Committee in March, unanimous. And there's hearings on both the house and the Senate this week to continue to discuss it. So we remain positive -- cautious but positive that we'll be able to get something through in this session. If we don't, and the likelihood is that we're not going to get a bill then we have to address the long-term profitability of the units, and we'll decide that as we see the legislative session end.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your expected generation guidance for 2015 to 2017 in New England is 2x, 2x plus today versus what it was in the fourth quarter release. You haven't acquired any assets, so can you explain how you've been able to double your expected generation in that ma
componenttext: Your expected generation guidance for 2015 to 2017 in New England is 2x, 2x plus today versus what it was in the fourth quarter release. You haven't acquired any assets, so can you explain how you've been able to double your expected generation in that market and the flow through impact it's having on your expected gross margin which looks like it's up marginally over the next 2 years but then down marginally in '17?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, it's Joe, I'll speak to that. And you're right, you noticed that our expected generation in New England in all years has increased appreciably. And as such, that generation percentage hedge has declined with that increased output of generation. Very
componenttext: Greg, it's Joe, I'll speak to that. And you're right, you noticed that our expected generation in New England in all years has increased appreciably. And as such, that generation percentage hedge has declined with that increased output of generation. Very simply, we had disclosed in Q4 '13 that we had worked with a fuel supplier to restructure a contract that we have. And if you remember back then, our generation had dropped by about 50% net quarter-over-quarter at that time. That contract restructuring has been terminated and it will be effective at the end of June this year. And the contract itself will revert back to its original terms and conditions. It has 2 impacts: one, you're seeing the generation impact and the hedge percentage impact and the notification of that termination was at the end of the first quarter this year. So really, you're seeing it flow through on an immediate basis. The gross margin impact was very minimal across the horizon and as such, just mechanically when you look at the hedge disclosure, the dollars of the termination of the contract restructuring as well as the increased value, the generation outlook and the margin associated with that is all flowing through open gross margin line, and it's very minimal. So really, it's a volume change that you see with little dollar impact.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So then what's the economic rationale for termination if it's more or less NPV neutral? Are these fuel contracts for gas plants that have optionality associated with price volatility? Are they base load? Why would you terminate that contract if it wasn't
componenttext: So then what's the economic rationale for termination if it's more or less NPV neutral? Are these fuel contracts for gas plants that have optionality associated with price volatility? Are they base load? Why would you terminate that contract if it wasn't increasing NPV appreciably?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't say too much due to the confidentiality of the nature of the agreement. But I will say is the contract termination was the right of the supplier who held that right. And from our perspective, as I said, the impact economically was very muted. I ca
componenttext: I can't say too much due to the confidentiality of the nature of the agreement. But I will say is the contract termination was the right of the supplier who held that right. And from our perspective, as I said, the impact economically was very muted. I can't speak to the supplier's perspective on why they terminated, but it's related to a long-term supply arrangement that we have.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to focus on the CP product, if we could. First, with regards to your expectations on future retirements, I'm curious, do you see the CPE product as proposed, driving retirements as you go to 100% CP market? Is that conceivable? And what kind o
componenttext: So I wanted to focus on the CP product, if we could. First, with regards to your expectations on future retirements, I'm curious, do you see the CPE product as proposed, driving retirements as you go to 100% CP market? Is that conceivable? And what kind of units? And then subsequently, obviously, with Supreme Court here waiting on the DR decision, how do you see that ultimately impacting the base in CP products of any eventual auction here? Does it appreciably impact CP, or is it more of an impact on the base option?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Julien, it's Joe. I think to your first question around retirements, we don't see a material impact. I mean, I think the rationale is first and foremost, obviously, to improve reliability on the system. And to do that, you need a couple of -- we can go ab
componenttext: Julien, it's Joe. I think to your first question around retirements, we don't see a material impact. I mean, I think the rationale is first and foremost, obviously, to improve reliability on the system. And to do that, you need a couple of -- we can go about that a couple of ways. One is the hardening of the units themselves which have a cost associated with it. The second thing is to make sure you have affirmed [ph] fuel on sites for these units and there's a cost to do that. When you look at the economics of all that, we don't believe there's going to be material impact to return. I will sit here and say though, given this structure that's been laid out if it is implemented, I would expect that you would see an increased risk premium effectively in the marketplace, given the fact that the penalty structure is changing rightfully so to ensure reliability. But I don't think out right, there will be a material impact on the retirement side.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the management?
componenttext: And on the management?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, from a DR perspective, there's a lot of fluffs around the rules. But sitting here, looking at this auction, we would expect to see that the demand response activity will continue in the way it has. And then as you see -- as rule changes through t
componenttext: I guess, from a DR perspective, there's a lot of fluffs around the rules. But sitting here, looking at this auction, we would expect to see that the demand response activity will continue in the way it has. And then as you see -- as rule changes through time, if the change, whether it becomes a retail product as opposed to wholesale product, we'll have to see how that plays out.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then just turning to the renewals business. Obviously, the yieldco phenomenon continues to evolve. Have you given more thought about the degree to which this business is core as we've seen the sort of market evolve?
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then just turning to the renewals business. Obviously, the yieldco phenomenon continues to evolve. Have you given more thought about the degree to which this business is core as we've seen the sort of market evolve?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mean with respect to the renewables part of our business?
componenttext: You mean with respect to the renewables part of our business?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Exactly. Just not with creating a structure itself but ultimately, whether you could kind of garner better value in the public markets of late.
componenttext: Exactly. Just not with creating a structure itself but ultimately, whether you could kind of garner better value in the public markets of late.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: As you know, we have an extensive business both on the solar as well as wind renewables part of our business. And how we've improved the returns on that business over the last number of years has been through the extensive use of project financing as a me
componenttext: As you know, we have an extensive business both on the solar as well as wind renewables part of our business. And how we've improved the returns on that business over the last number of years has been through the extensive use of project financing as a means of returning capital to the corporate conference to reinvest either in the growth of the utilities or fund some of our other expansionary efforts around, as an example, the peaker that we're building in New England or the combined cycles we're building in Texas. Certainly, we do watch and we do evaluate and consider the potential impact of value that a yieldco could have on our assets from the perspective of yieldcos as potential buyers of those assets or through the potential to create our own yieldco. And we continue to evaluate that within our project financing efforts. We have retained that option to be able to do that. I think one of the key elements though, to a successful strategy around yieldcos is having a significant and visible pipeline of assets that you could drop down. And we have, I think, a good amount of assets. We have some elements like our Enova LNG facility that if we decide to pursue that and we had a long-term offtake agreement that would provide attractive revenues that could fit in that type of structure. But at this point, we don't have any plans to pursue such a structure and continue to have a candidly wait-and-see approach.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. So more of a retain the business, build it out and then see down the line rather than monetize today?
componenttext: All right. So more of a retain the business, build it out and then see down the line rather than monetize today?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. So you'll see us continuing to deploy wind investments. We have a project that we're developing down in Texas, in dero [ph]. You continue to see us work down a path on the Enova LNG project to secure a long term offtake, and you see us -- thro
componenttext: Absolutely. So you'll see us continuing to deploy wind investments. We have a project that we're developing down in Texas, in dero [ph]. You continue to see us work down a path on the Enova LNG project to secure a long term offtake, and you see us -- through our Constellation business, continue to pursue opportunities to grow the solar side of our business.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Neel Mitra with Tudor, Pickering.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neel Mitra with Tudor, Pickering.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wondering on the Holdco side, how more debt are you able to support after the Pepco acquisition closes now that you're more regulated?
componenttext: Just wondering on the Holdco side, how more debt are you able to support after the Pepco acquisition closes now that you're more regulated?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Neel, as you know, we have significant debt issuance forthcoming that will be used to finance at the holding company, the PHI transaction that we would look to reach markets once we have visibility around a successful path in Maryland. We've continued to
componenttext: Neel, as you know, we have significant debt issuance forthcoming that will be used to finance at the holding company, the PHI transaction that we would look to reach markets once we have visibility around a successful path in Maryland. We've continued to evaluate the balance sheet capacity and the space that we have at that holding company. As you know, we've said we'll utilize that holding company as a potential vehicle to finance regulated growth. I think an important element of this is the interplay between the growing earnings mix of our utilities business relative to our merchant exposure on how the rating agencies perceive us. And so to the extent that the rating agencies continue to evolve in their thinking around the risks embedded in our business and see us as the less risky credit, I would say that's the biggest mover of balance sheet capacity. Obviously, some elements around whether it's capacity performance, the Illinois Clean Energy Legislation that would be additive to the company's cash flow and earnings, would also be helpful to our ability to add further leverage to the holding company.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Got it. And then assuming Pepco closes, what's the latest update as to when the dividend is fully funded by the regulated side?

componenttextpreview: So we project that towards the latter part of the decade into 2020 time frame, but we'll continue to evaluate that based off of rate case outcomes.
componenttext: So we project that towards the latter part of the decade into 2020 time frame, but we'll continue to evaluate that based off of rate case outcomes.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Neel, that's not specific to that from a free cash flow standpoint, the utilities being able to not just from a payout ratio standpoint, but from a free cash flow funding standpoint. Chris's point on the latter part of the decade is when that cash wou
componenttext: And Neel, that's not specific to that from a free cash flow standpoint, the utilities being able to not just from a payout ratio standpoint, but from a free cash flow funding standpoint. Chris's point on the latter part of the decade is when that cash would be available to potentially consider growing the dividend.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then last on the Illinois legislation. If something isn't reached by the end of May, what are the options to maybe keep the process going through 2015? Or is it kind of done through the rest of the year if you don't have outcome by May?
componenttext: Great. And then last on the Illinois legislation. If something isn't reached by the end of May, what are the options to maybe keep the process going through 2015? Or is it kind of done through the rest of the year if you don't have outcome by May?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There is a -- we expect the session -- this is Bill Von Hoene, to conclude at the end of May, if conceivably it could be extended if the budget impasse continues. It's unlikely that the energy legislation would be considered during that period of time. Th
componenttext: There is a -- we expect the session -- this is Bill Von Hoene, to conclude at the end of May, if conceivably it could be extended if the budget impasse continues. It's unlikely that the energy legislation would be considered during that period of time. There is a 6-day veto session in November and into early December which requires a supermajority on any votes that passed during that period of time. So that would be the next time the legislation would convene after the conclusion of this regular session.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And a supermajority would require 60% vote, is that correct?
componenttext: And a supermajority would require 60% vote, is that correct?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The point on that though, in May of 2014, we committed not to make any decisions based off of the economics for a year. We're coming to the end of that year and we need to make decisions that start the planning process if we do not see a success path.
componenttext: The point on that though, in May of 2014, we committed not to make any decisions based off of the economics for a year. We're coming to the end of that year and we need to make decisions that start the planning process if we do not see a success path.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Angie Storozynski with Macquarie.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to focus again on Illinois. So it seems like you guys have bullish energy prices in Illinois and that's why you're not hedging much of your portfolio. You're also bullish on the capacity prices, at least in PJM. You just had this spike in MISO
componenttext: So I wanted to focus again on Illinois. So it seems like you guys have bullish energy prices in Illinois and that's why you're not hedging much of your portfolio. You're also bullish on the capacity prices, at least in PJM. You just had this spike in MISO capacity. So how [indiscernible] that up? Because on the one hand, if capacity prices rise, then you have less of a volatility on peak [indiscernible] invest potentially lower heat rates. So how does it reconcile with your outlook on heat rates?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. This is Joe. I think that what I would say is, if we talk just about energy prices in Northern Illinois for a minute, using prices as of the end of the quarter, we do still see heat rate expansion. We don't think the market is priced in or t
componenttext: Good morning. This is Joe. I think that what I would say is, if we talk just about energy prices in Northern Illinois for a minute, using prices as of the end of the quarter, we do still see heat rate expansion. We don't think the market is priced in or the upside really driven by back up the changing dispatch stack. And if you think about 2 different timeframes like '16, '17, we probably see less upside than we do when you get out to the '18, '19 time period and it's probably to the tune of $22 [ph] accordingly. Just as importantly, we also have a view that we think natural gas is underpriced at this point which would in addition to that, would drive prices higher net-net because you would see a slight heat rate decline with the rising natural gas but net-net, it would be a positive outcome. And your point is right, that's from a hedging perspective. We continue to remain behind our ratable hedging plan in the Midwest to the tune of about 10% in '16 and '17 approximately, just given those views.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And secondly, in ERCOT. So you keep saying that you have a cost advantage for the new build, and you clearly do. But forward curves are showing on peak spark spreads of $15, $16. So the conclusion or your dedication to the project is driven by your
componenttext: Okay. And secondly, in ERCOT. So you keep saying that you have a cost advantage for the new build, and you clearly do. But forward curves are showing on peak spark spreads of $15, $16. So the conclusion or your dedication to the project is driven by your outlook on where these sparks are going to go as opposed to what we're seeing? And so, I mean, can you give us at least a sense what kind of sparks left you're assuming in your calculations when you think that the IRR of the project is still interesting?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Angie, it's Ken. We continue to be comfortable with our investments in these plans. Because of as Chris said, the cost advantage, the technology advantage, meaning the heat rate efficiencies and the responsiveness of this plant, we've seen spark spreads b
componenttext: Angie, it's Ken. We continue to be comfortable with our investments in these plans. Because of as Chris said, the cost advantage, the technology advantage, meaning the heat rate efficiencies and the responsiveness of this plant, we've seen spark spreads bounce around a lot in ERCOT. The lack of volatility recently has driven down. Our long-term fundamental views are what I would say conservative, and we're still confident in the investment, very confident, actually.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just sticking with the RSSA with Ginna, is there an update on the filing? And then just counter with EDF put option, is there like, how should we think about under an assumption that you may own the remaining portion of this plant? Is there an option that
componenttext: Just sticking with the RSSA with Ginna, is there an update on the filing? And then just counter with EDF put option, is there like, how should we think about under an assumption that you may own the remaining portion of this plant? Is there an option that you can get an expanded RSA contract if the timing works?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Bill Von Hoene. The RSSA contract was approved by FERC effective April 1 but with 2 adjustments being required in the contract which has been sent back and a compliance filing will be made by Ginna to reflect that. And there will be a process by w
componenttext: This is Bill Von Hoene. The RSSA contract was approved by FERC effective April 1 but with 2 adjustments being required in the contract which has been sent back and a compliance filing will be made by Ginna to reflect that. And there will be a process by which the contract itself will be evaluated and potentially settled through a FERC procedure. So that is going to go forward for probably the balance of the year, based upon precedents and other circumstances. Although the ability to collect on a cost-save base rate is effective now. The put is exercisable by EDF. January 1, 2016, we do not know and don't speculate as to what would happen in connection with that with regard to the potential extension of the RSSA agreement. It's predicated on the period of time that's necessary for the New York system to find alternative ways to deliver the same reliability that Ginna currently is required to deliver. So we would not anticipate in the absence of the failure of the New York system to do so, that there could be any basis for extension of the agreement.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one lastly, just sticking with the Illinois carbon portfolio. Is there -- have you quantified what could potentially be available under the cap using, let's say, the 2014 rates? And then additionally, am I correct to assume that ther
componenttext: Got it. And then just one lastly, just sticking with the Illinois carbon portfolio. Is there -- have you quantified what could potentially be available under the cap using, let's say, the 2014 rates? And then additionally, am I correct to assume that there's an opportunity to breach that cap if somehow, credits are being constrained?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. The cap is same. Essentially, 2% cap that goes on energy efficiency and RPS. And I think that's been calculated by a number of folks. There is no provision by which the cap could be breached under the legislation as it's currently proposed.
componenttext: No. The cap is same. Essentially, 2% cap that goes on energy efficiency and RPS. And I think that's been calculated by a number of folks. There is no provision by which the cap could be breached under the legislation as it's currently proposed.

componenttext: No, we have not.
