componenttext: Good morning. Thank you for standing by. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation Quarter 2 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'd now like to turn the today's conference over to Francis Idehen. Thank you, you may begin.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Holly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our second quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; Joe Nigro, CEO of Constellation; and Jack Thayer,
componenttext:
Thank you, Holly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our second quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; Joe Nigro, CEO of Constellation; and Jack Thayer, Chief Financial Officer. They are joined by other members of Exelon management team and will be available to answer your questions following our prepared remarks. 
We issued our earnings release this morning, along with a presentation, each of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. The earnings release and other matters, which we discussed during today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in today's material, comments made during this call and in the Risk Factors section of the 10-K, which we filed in February as well as in the earnings release and the 10-Q, which we expect to file later today. Please refer to the 10-K, today's 8-K and 10-Q and Exelon's other filings for a discussion of factors that may cause the results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations. 
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for a reconciliation between the non-GAAP measures to the nearest equivalent GAAP measures.  We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Francis, good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining. We're pleased to report another strong quarter with our earnings coming in at $0.59 per share, surpassing our guidance of $0.45 to $0.55 per share. You'll hear more from Jack in a minute on the
componenttext:
Thanks, Francis, good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining. We're pleased to report another strong quarter with our earnings coming in at $0.59 per share, surpassing our guidance of $0.45 to $0.55 per share. You'll hear more from Jack in a minute on the specifics and Joe Nigro also provide some color around the performance. 
We've seen a number of positive developments that affect various business this quarter. The 2 primary catalysts for us this year are the PHI acquisition and the capacity market auctions. We received the approval from the merger since our last call in Maryland in May. And leaving D.C -- Washington, D.C. as our only outstanding jurisdiction to close the merger, which we expect to hear from soon, and we're looking forward to a positive outcome there. Upon closing the merger, our focus will shift to the integration of PHI utilities into the Exelon utilities to align our operations to better serve the PHI customers base. 
Another major catalyst is the capacity performance revisions that have been made. While we continue to believe that FERC came to the right conclusion putting reliability at the center of its planning process to ensure that customers in the region are well served. We always -- we're aware that DR and energy efficiency were in the '18, '19 [ph] auction, that the most recent change that allows DR and energy efficiency to provide -- to participate in a transition auctions, we believe, to be nonmaterial to the outcome. 
We are disappointed in the delay, but we think that we'll be on the right track and to recognize the value of our highly reliable fleet going forward. 
And we remain confident that capacity construct is the best way to protect the grid as we await further clarification on the timing of these transition auctions. I think we're getting that in the last days. So by the September time frame, we should have clear -- clarity on the value proposition, along with the reliability measures being enacted. 
In Illinois, the legislative session ended without a resolution on the market redesign for the low carbon standard, the low carbon portfolio standard. We were disappointed that we were not able to get this outcome before the session ended but understand where the state is focused right now on its budget priorities. The nuclear plants provide a significant value to the state and its economy and it's mostly important to its consumers.
Looking ahead, we have certain regulatory and operational triggers in September that require us to make some tough choices on the specific assets this fall, particularly in light of the continued pressure on the power markets. So. we're continuing on with our disciplined plan on evaluating the assets and they're likelihood to stay within the stack and we'll bring that to closure with our decision in September. 
Despite these market challenges, we continue to find ways to create value in our Constellation business, which Joe is going to talk about shortly. Part of our resilience to the power market weakness is driven by our ability to capitalize on generation to load strategy. In this quarter, we showed the benefit from the lower cost to serve load. And increasing our Utility business has been able to reduce the overall volatility at the enterprise level and deliver growth. 
You can expect that even more to be true over time, not only is it shifting our business mix with the acquisition of PHI, but it also, with our infrastructure improvement investments, we're investing $16 billion in our existing utilities over the next 5 years, which provides respectable growth rates and roughly another $7 billion with the addition of PHI.
I want to remind everybody that we can perform well even with the rising interest rate environment, which is typically a headwind in our industry. This is because our EPS is positively correlated to interest rates due to both ComEd's formula rate and ROE being tied to the 30-year treasury rate as well as the discount of our pension -- discounting the rates of our pension liability. Overall, we are positive the company is able to provide more stable and durable earnings streams for our shareholders with our operational expertise in driving performance across the enterprise.
With that, I'll turn it over to Joe who will discuss the markets, followed by Jack on the financial performance.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. The Constellation business is continuing to perform well in 2015 as a result of our generation to load matching strategy. My comments today will address market events during the second quarter and and what the
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. The Constellation business is continuing to perform well in 2015 as a result of our generation to load matching strategy. My comments today will address market events during the second quarter and and what they mean for our commercial business going forward, including our hedging strategy and our updated disclosures.
Starting with Slide 4. The spot held market in the second quarter has been defined by mild weather and lower gas prices, which drove the price of power considerably lower than in 2014 across all of PJM. The impact of low spot market condition has carried through to the forward market with prices down approximately $0.45 per megawatt hour in 2016 and $1 per megawatt hour in 2017 as well as the PGM West Hub and NiHub since the end of the first quarter. 
The lack of liquidity in the forward markets has exacerbated the drops in power prices and heat rates with the forward markets exhibiting volatile price moves on very little trading volume for calendar 2017 and beyond, especially at NiHub. 
During the quarter, our hedging activities for 2016 to 2018 were executed to our retail and wholesale load businesses rather than on the over-the-counter market. Our fundamental view of power prices has not changed but given the drop in market prices, there is a greater gap between the market and our fundamental the aged to current a natural gas prices expected retirements, new generation resources and load assumptions.   
Moving to Slide 5, I'll discuss the forward market and impact on our hedging profile. During the second quarter, we maintained our behind ratable strategy and increased our cross commodity hedge position to increase exposure to power price upside. We had successfully used this behind ratable hedging strategy in the past when our view showed upside in the market. We are 4% to 5% behind ratable in 2016, and '17 and 7% to 8% behind ratable if you remove our cross commodity hedges at NiHub. We are confident in our ability to adjust our hedging strategy to capitalize on our fundamental view.
Turning to Slide 6, I will review our updated hedge disclosure and some key changes since the end of the first quarter. In 2015, we have a net $50 million increase to total gross margin since the end of the first quarter, driven primarily by strong performance and execution. We executed on $200 million of power new business and $50 million of nonpower new business during train the quarter. Based on 2015 performance to-date and expectations for the full year, we have increased our power new business target by $50 million.
Our generation to load strategy was successful last year during the extreme forward vortex conditions and in serving us as well under weaker load and price conditions. It is further augmented by strong performance from our portfolio optimization activity and our Integrys acquisition. 
For 2016, we saw prices decreased across most regions, decreasing around $0.45 per megawatt hour in both the mid-Atlantic and the Midwest. This resulted in a decrease in our open gross margin of approximately $200 million, which is offset by our hedging activities.
During the quarter, we executed $100 million of power new business and $50 million of nonpower new business, and our raising our power new business target by $50 million additional due to commercial opportunities for a gross margin increase of $50 million in 2016.
For 2017, prices decreased by approximately $1 per megawatt hour in both the mid-Atlantic and Midwest. These resulted in a decrease of $300 million in our open gross margin. Despite the drop in prices, our total gross margin is only down $50 million due to our hedge position and an increase in our power new business target of $100 million because we have line of sight into additional commercial opportunities.
Since the beginning of the year, prices have fallen due to mild weather, lower gas prices, lower load demand in the Midwest and the lack of liquidity in the market. Prices have fallen more than 2017 and beyond than in 2016. Although this weakness and spot market impacted forward markets, we are fundamental be of the view of the gas and power markets and are positioning our portfolio to take advantage of this.
Now I'll turn it over to Jack to review the full financial information for the quarter.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe, and good morning, everyone, and we had another strong quarter. Our remarks we will cover our financial results for the quarter, third quarter range constraints and our cash outlook.Starting with our second quarter results on Slide 7, Exe
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe, and good morning, everyone, and we had another strong quarter. Our remarks we will cover our financial results for the quarter, third quarter range constraints and our cash outlook.
Starting with our second quarter results on Slide 7, Exelon exceeded our guidance range and delivered earnings of $0.59 per share. This compares to $0.51 per share for the second quarter of 2014. Exelon's utilities delivered combined earnings of $0.25 per share, and were flat to the second quarter of last year. During the quarter, we saw favorable weather at PECO and unfavorable weather at ComEd. 
Cooling degree days were up nearly 37% from the prior year and 47.4% above normal in the South Eastern Pennsylvania and down 34% from the prior year and 21.6% below normal in northern Illinois. Distribution revenues at ComEd and BGE were higher quarter-over-quarter. In addition, BGE had a decrease in uncollectible accounts expense compared to the second quarter of 2014.
Exelon Generation had another strong quarter, delivering earnings of $0.36 per share, $0.09 higher than the same period last year. As Joe mentioned, our generation to load matching strategy continues to prove effective. We benefited from a lower cost to serve, both our retail and also customers and has strong performance from our portfolio management team. In addition, compared to the second quarter of 2014, we had fewer average days at our nuclear plants, which had a positive contribution from the Integrys acquisition, higher realized nuclear decommissioning trust fund gains and received additional benefits quarter-over-quarter from the cancellation of the DOE's spend nuclear feet. These positive factors were partially offset by higher tax and interest expense. More detail on the quarter-over-quarter drivers for each operating company can be found on Slides 18 and 19 in the appendix.
For the third quarter, we are providing guidance of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. Accounting for the effect of the increased share accounts, and then associated with the Pepco Holdings transaction and assuming the transaction closes in the third quarter, we are narrowing our full year guidance from $2.25 to $2.55 per share to $2.35 to $2.55 per share. Our guidance does not assume that bonus depreciation is extended.
Slide 8 provides an update on our cash flow expectations for this year. We've simplified the format of our slide to provide a clearer view of our cash flow at each operating company, including explicitly showing free cash flow. We project cash flow from operations of $6.6 billion. We project free cash flow of $900 million in generation in 2015. 80% of our total gross capital expenditures are being invested in our utilities over the next 3 years, which will provide stable earnings growth. 
In June, we completed the debt portion of our financing for the PECO transaction by issuing $4.2 billion in senior notes with the majority of these proceeds being used to fund this transaction. Strong market demand allowed us to upsize the offering, enabling us to pull forward some future planned corporate debt issuances. We expect with an average maturity of approximately 14 years and an average weighted average coupon of 3.79%.
Earlier this month, we completed the settlement of the equity forward transaction. The combination of these financings allows us to close the merger quickly upon receiving approval from the D.C. Public Service Commission. Our balance sheet remains strong and gives us the ability to invest and grow our business. As a reminder, the appendix includes several schedules that will help you in your modeling efforts.
Thank you, and we'll now open the lines for questions.

componenttext: A couple of questions. First, when you talk about the commercial opportunities in the context of your comfort level raising your guidance for power new business to go, are we talking about sort of the inherent counter cyclicality of the margins in that business in the low wholesale environment, i.e., are we moving closer off the $2 floor in margins and closer to the $4 sort of peak at the cycle margins that you see in that business historically? Or is it simply new customers more volumes than you had projected in either the gas or electric business?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg. In this specific entity, specifically, for 2016 where we're raising our power new business to grow by $50 million and 2017 by $100 million, it's really -- It's not related to those load. It's more specifically related to proprietary structured
componenttext: Yes, Greg. In this specific entity, specifically, for 2016 where we're raising our power new business to grow by $50 million and 2017 by $100 million, it's really -- It's not related to those load. It's more specifically related to proprietary structured commercial opportunities that we have really solid line of sight into on our wholesale side of the business, quite frankly. To your point though, I think it's important to note we have raised our target to $50 million each quarter for 2015 for a total of $100 million so far year-to-date and a lot of that has been driven by really 3 things. One is the monetization of loads that result in higher prices last year. So we have seen increased value from that load serving business. Some of our optimization activities, and then we went in, as you saw from our disclosures last quarter, we went in a short bias with the backstop of our own generation and given the results of market prices that in '15 to date, that performed well. We would only look to raise those targets, the power to go target to our nonpowered go targets if we have good line of sight into specific opportunities and in this case, we do.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, what I would say is our view of the absolute value of power price hasn't changed quarter-over-quarter. And what's changed we saw a material drop in the back end of the power curve, and I'm talking to NiHub but it's attributable to West Hub as
componenttext: Yes, Steve, what I would say is our view of the absolute value of power price hasn't changed quarter-over-quarter. And what's changed we saw a material drop in the back end of the power curve, and I'm talking to NiHub but it's attributable to West Hub as well. But our upside is baked at NiHub where we really see material upside as you move-out into that '18, '19 time frame. We see upside as well in that '16, '17 period and what's changed is that the market ahs fallen so much quarter-over-quarter. Our absolute view of the power price hasn't changed so that spread has gone wider. And when we look at our fundamental models at NiHubin, in particular, we see a lot of value that still be derived. And that's due to the changing dispatch some of the other things that we've talked about previously.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Talk about the lack of liquidity.
componenttext: Talk about the lack of liquidity.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The liquidity piece of it is a big part of it, Steve. We had a $0.40, approximately $0.40 megawatt hour drop in PJM in NiHub and West Hub in calender 2016. That's the most liquid period on the forward curve. When we pull data that we have access to a
componenttext: Yes. The liquidity piece of it is a big part of it, Steve. We had a $0.40, approximately $0.40 megawatt hour drop in PJM in NiHub and West Hub in calender 2016. That's the most liquid period on the forward curve. When we pull data that we have access to and look what's going on in the out-years, '18, '19, '20, where we saw a material drop in prices, there is absolutely nothing trading at NiHub. There had been few sporadic trades at West Hub and you see the markets prices off of those trades and our view is, through time, that spread relationship between West Hub and NiHub is going to collapse because of the retirement from the Western side, the newbuilds on the Eastern side, and that's why we think there's material upside. But our fundamental absolute view on power price has changed. It's just the way the market reacted quarter-over-quarter.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We expect to, assuming an acceptable order from the D.C. commission, we expect to close promptly after that order. Our contract would indicate that, that would take place within 48 hours approval by the D.C. commission. And we don't think that the Marylan
componenttext: We expect to, assuming an acceptable order from the D.C. commission, we expect to close promptly after that order. Our contract would indicate that, that would take place within 48 hours approval by the D.C. commission. And we don't think that the Maryland motion should be any bar to us the stores closings. We don't believe that, that motion has any merit whatsoever. As you know, the alleged conflict of interest one of the commissioners having a preliminary interview and discussion, which she stopped with a nonparty isn't the basis under Maryland law to question the independence of that decision, let alone to stay the proceedings. No court in Maryland and no commission in Maryland has ever suggested that there is a conflict with a Commissioner of any agency having a conversation with a nonparty, particularly, whereas here, Exelon is 1 of some 25 board members, 140 members in an agency that includes public-interest movements like Public Citizen. There was a party below and was the first one to raise this conflict issue. So we don't think that, that motion is any merit. We filed a response yesterday with the court, and we plan to go ahead and close probably after the D.C. commission issues in order, assuming that, that order has acceptable conditions and we have the faith that the D.C. commission will do the right thing. We think we've put in a strong case with the a lot of benefits for customers and protection for customers. And we look forward to a prompt closing.

And does that force your hand come October?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The capacity market fixes focus on reliability will not be enough to keep all the units economically viable. It does give us some support for the investments that we continue to make on the assets, to maintain the reliability but it's not totally there. W
componenttext: The capacity market fixes focus on reliability will not be enough to keep all the units economically viable. It does give us some support for the investments that we continue to make on the assets, to maintain the reliability but it's not totally there. We need a market fix in Illinois to stop the noncompetitive nature of the market. And short of the legislation to fix that, we will have to make decisions on retiring assets that are not economically viable. As we talked about previously, we have requirements around modification to PJM of our intent to retire prepare units, it's an 18 month notification. We also have commitments around when we have to notify of our availability for the '18, '19 auction in participation on that. And very importantly, we have to order and design course that, course to take a while for us to '19, '20 auctions, I said '18, '19. '19, '20 auctions, our participation there. And we have to order the course. And there's a little lead time there, and we're going to run for an additional year. We're going to run for a longer period of time come, and that's a very to expensive decision to make. So at least on the PJM assets, we'll make the decision, the final decision. We're going to do that in the September time frame. We've been in consultation with the board and we'll continue to consult with the board. Where management has made their decision, we'll ask that to the board for final approval. And in that time frame, and continue with outreach to our stakeholders.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If the units clear, the '18, '19 auction, that would show that they're financially viable. That is a long shot, in our opinion, just because of the cost structure and how the forwards have continued to collapse at a couple of these units where we get the
componenttext: If the units clear, the '18, '19 auction, that would show that they're financially viable. That is a long shot, in our opinion, just because of the cost structure and how the forwards have continued to collapse at a couple of these units where we get the transmission constraints, we've got the overproduction and importation of wind that not only drops the spot but continues to collapse the forward curve. The disconnect between NiHub and the buzz at some of these units is $6, $7. And we have worked very closely with all the stakeholders involved for over 1.5 years on trying to come to resolution and it is the time that we'll have to make the decision after, we see what happens with the capacity auctions. We don't take the decision lightly. We understand the effect that we have on the communities and the potential effect on employees. But this has been a long-term issue that we've been evaluating and trying to come to resolution. And we're staying within the time line actually, we extended our time last year to give a more time to come up with the proper market fixes and to be compensated adequately for operating these units versus subsidizing a low-cost market.

componenttextpreview: John, it's Joe. First of all, we lost over $1 billion of market cap post the announcement of that of the inclusion of DR in '16, '17 and '17, '18, and we really thought it was a little bit of an overreaction. As Chris mentioned, we're disappointed in the
componenttext: John, it's Joe. First of all, we lost over $1 billion of market cap post the announcement of that of the inclusion of DR in '16, '17 and '17, '18, and we really thought it was a little bit of an overreaction. As Chris mentioned, we're disappointed in the way, but we don't believe there's going to be a material impact to either those transition auctions. As you're aware, DR was already in included in '18, '19 and beyond. The reason we don't think it's a material impact in the transition auction is really related to how the auctions itself cleared on the base residual and the separation in price in '16, '17 on one side, and then the amount of DR that cleared in '17, '18 auction. And when we put that all into our model, it's very similar to what we read quite friendly from a lot of what's been written by the equity community that it's going to be a limited impact.

componenttext: Yes, we've discussed, fairly openly the units, the affected units. PJM's rules requires us an earlier notification and MISO's rules. And so we would be moving forward if we have to on PJM units before MISO units. We don't project a MISO decision until beginning of next year looking at the opportunities we have with that unit even through legislation or other mechanisms to secure the required revenues that we need there. We talked about New York units where we're still working with our partners and our stakeholders in New York to look at is there a viable way beyond, or a reliability must ran situation to maintain economic viability there. And the final asset has been in discussion is Oyster Creek, which we've already had agreed-upon early retirement dates at the end of 2019. So short of a -- short of some type of failure that was a costly failure on the unit, we would run into that period allow adequate transition. Utilization of the fuel in adequate transition of our employee base to other facilities.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Darryl again. Yes, the President on a stay is very clear in Maryland. It's an extraordinary remedy. It is rarely granted. You have to show a likelihood of success on the merits. And the motion does not, on the merits of the underlying merger, raise a
componenttext: It's Darryl again. Yes, the President on a stay is very clear in Maryland. It's an extraordinary remedy. It is rarely granted. You have to show a likelihood of success on the merits. And the motion does not, on the merits of the underlying merger, raise any issues whatsoever. The only issue it raise is claim, which we think is very, very weak. So we don't think attempt to meet that. We also have to show irreparable harm, which they spent a paragraph trying to satisfy that. It's really not very persuasive in our view. They would have to show that it stays in the public interest. And of course, not only as the Maryland commission, but the New Jersey commission, the FERC, the Delaware commission have all found that this merger isn't a public interest and they have also to show that the favor them and our we layout why disrupting the potentially disrupting a $7 billion merger outweighs any hardships that would occur from the [indiscernible]. So we think it's an extraordinary remedy. We don't think that they've come close to meeting those standards in any respect and also very clear that in Maryland, it's not a balancing. They have satisfy each and everyone of those elements and in this case, in our view, they haven't satisfied any of them. So that leaves us in a position where upon D.C. approval and assuming that the court agrees with the we filed yesterday and doesn't grant a stay that promptly upon the D.C. commission joining the other commissions and the timing this isn't a public interest and assuming that's any conditions that it imposes are not the unduly burdensome that we would close promptly.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There is no clock in D.C. So they are not under any time constraint. Generally, the D.C. commission has ruled within 90 days of something being fully brief and submitted to them. This was fully briefed at the end of the May. So that 90 days would end
componenttext: Yes. There is no clock in D.C. So they are not under any time constraint. Generally, the D.C. commission has ruled within 90 days of something being fully brief and submitted to them. This was fully briefed at the end of the May. So that 90 days would end at the end of August. I think that's where that date comes from. Obviously, we're hopeful that sooner is better than later. But that will be up to the D.C. commission and that they'll rule when they have finished their work there. I think acutely aware that a lot of people are looking court decisions from them and they understand that. But they'll take the time that they need necessary in order to do their job right.

componenttext: Good morning. Thank you for standing by. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation Quarter 2 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn today's conference over to Francis Idehen. Thank you, you may begin.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Holly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our second quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; Joe Nigro, CEO of Constellation; and Jack Thayer,
componenttext:
Thank you, Holly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our second quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; Joe Nigro, CEO of Constellation; and Jack Thayer, Chief Financial Officer. They're joined by other members of Exelon management team, who will be available to answer your questions following our prepared remarks. 
We issued our earnings release this morning, along with a presentation, each of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. The earnings release and other matters, which we discuss during today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in today's material, comments made during this call and in the Risk Factors section of the 10-K, which we filed in February as well as in the earnings release and the 10-Q, which we expect to file later today. Please refer to the 10-K, today's 8-K and 10-Q and Exelon's other filings for a discussion of factors that may cause the results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations. 
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for a reconciliation between the non-GAAP measures to the nearest equivalent GAAP measures.  We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Francis, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining. We're pleased to report another strong quarter with our earnings coming in at $0.59 per share, surpassing our guidance of $0.45 to $0.55 per share. You'll hear more from Jack in a minute on
componenttext:
Thanks, Francis, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining. We're pleased to report another strong quarter with our earnings coming in at $0.59 per share, surpassing our guidance of $0.45 to $0.55 per share. You'll hear more from Jack in a minute on the specifics and Joe Nigro also provide some color around the performance. 
We've seen a number of positive developments that affect various business this quarter. The 2 primary catalysts for us this year are the PHI acquisition and the capacity market auctions. We received the approval from the merger since our last call in Maryland in May. And leaving D.C., Washington, D.C. as our only outstanding jurisdiction to close the merger, which we expect to hear from soon, and we're looking forward to a positive outcome there. Upon closing the merger, our focus will shift to the integration of PHI utilities into the Exelon utilities to align our operations to better serve the PHI customers base. 
Another major catalyst is the capacity performance revisions that have been made. While we continue to believe that FERC came to the right conclusion putting reliability at the center of its planning process to ensure that customers in the region are well served, we always -- we're aware that DR and energy efficiency were in the '18, '19 auction, that the most recent change that allows DR and energy efficiency to provide -- to participate in a transition auctions, we believe, to be nonmaterial to the outcome. 
We are disappointed in the delay but we think that we'll be on the right track in to recognize the value of our highly reliable fleet going forward. 
And we remain confident that the capacity construct is the best way to protect the grid as we await further clarification on the timing of these transition auctions. I think we're getting that in the last days. So by the September time frame, we should have clear -- clarity on the value proposition, along with the reliability measures being enacted. 
In Illinois, the legislative session ended without a resolution on the market redesign for the low carbon standard, the low carbon portfolio standard. We were disappointed that we were not able to get this outcome before the session ended but understand where the state is focused right now on its budget priorities. The nuclear plants provide a significant value to the state and its economy and it's mostly important to its consumers.
Looking ahead, we have certain regulatory and operational triggers in September that require us to make some tough choices on the specific assets this fall, particularly in light of the continued pressure on the power markets. So we are continuing on with our disciplined plan on evaluating the assets and their likelihood to stay within the stack and we'll bring that to closure with our decision in September. 
Despite these market challenges, we continue to find ways to create value in our Constellation business, which Joe is going to talk about shortly. Part of our resilience to the power market weakness is driven by our ability to capitalize on our generation to load strategy. In this quarter, we showed the benefit from the lower cost to serve load, and increasing our utility business has been able to reduce the overall volatility at the enterprise level and deliver growth. 
You can expect that even more to be true over time, not only is it shifting our business mix with the acquisition of PHI, but it also, with our infrastructure improvement investments, we're investing $16 billion in our existing utilities over the next 5 years, which provides respectable growth rates and roughly another $7 billion with the addition of PHI.
I want to remind everybody that we can perform well even with the rising interest rate environment, which is typically a headwind in our industry. This is because our EPS is positively correlated to interest rates due to both ComEd's formula rate and ROE being tied to the 30-year treasury rate as well as the discount of our pension -- discounting the rates of our pension liability. Overall, we are positive the company is able to provide more stable and durable earnings streams for our shareholders with our operational expertise in driving performance across the enterprise.
With that, I'll turn it over to Joe, who will discuss the markets, followed by Jack on the financial performance.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. Good morning, everyone. The Constellation business is continuing to perform well in 2015 as a result of our generation to load matching strategy. My comments today will address market events during the second quarter and what they mean f
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. Good morning, everyone. The Constellation business is continuing to perform well in 2015 as a result of our generation to load matching strategy. My comments today will address market events during the second quarter and what they mean for our commercial business going forward, including our hedging strategy and our updated disclosures.
Starting with Slide 4. The spot power market in the second quarter has been defined by mild weather and lower natural gas prices, which drove the price of power considerably lower than in 2014 across all of PJM. The impact of low spot market condition has carried through to the forward markets with prices down approximately $0.45 per megawatt hour in 2016 and $1 per megawatt hour in 2017 as well as the PJM West Hub and NiHub since the end of the first quarter. 
The lack of liquidity in the forward markets has exacerbated the drops in power prices and heat rates with the forward markets exhibiting volatile price moves on very little trading volume for calendar 2017 and beyond, especially at NiHub. 
During the quarter, our hedging activities for 2016 to 2018 were executed to our retail and wholesale load businesses rather than on the over-the-counter market. Our fundamental view of power prices has not changed but given the drop in market prices, there is a greater gap between the market and our fundamental view due to current natural gas prices, expected retirements, new generation resources and load assumptions.   
Moving to Slide 5. I'll discuss the forward market and its impact on our hedging profile. During the second quarter, we maintained our behind ratable strategy and increased our cross commodity hedge position to increase exposure to power price upside. We had successfully used this behind ratable hedging strategy in the past when our view showed upside in the market. We are 4% to 5% behind ratable in 2016, and '17 and 7% to 8% behind ratable if you remove our cross commodity hedges at NiHub. We are confident in our ability to adjust our hedging strategies to capitalize on our fundamental view.
Turning to Slide 6, I will review our updated hedge disclosure and some key changes since the end of the first quarter. In 2015, we have a net $50 million increase to total gross margin since the end of the first quarter, driven primarily by strong performance and execution. We executed on $200 million of power new business and $50 million of non-power new business during the quarter. Based on 2015 performance to-date and expectations for the full year, we have increased our power new business target by $50 million.
Our generation to load strategy was successful last year during the extreme polar vortex conditions and it's serving us well this year under weaker load and price conditions. It is further augmented by strong performance from our portfolio optimization activity and our Integrys acquisition. 
For 2016, we saw prices decreased across most regions, decreasing around $0.45 per megawatt hour in both the Mid-Atlantic and the Midwest. This resulted in a decrease in our open gross margin of approximately $200 million, which was offset by our hedging activities.
During the quarter, we executed $100 million of power new business and $50 million of non-power new business, and are raising our power new business target by $50 million additional due to commercial opportunities for a gross margin increase of $50 million in 2016.
For 2017, prices decreased by approximately $1 per megawatt hour in both the Mid-Atlantic and Midwest. These resulted in a decrease of $300 million in our open gross margin. Despite the drop in prices, our total gross margin is only down $50 million due to our hedge position and an increase in our power new business target of $100 million because we have line of sight into additional commercial opportunities.
Since the beginning of the year, prices have fallen due to mild weather, lower gas prices, lower load demand in the Midwest and the lack of liquidity in the markets. Prices have fallen more in 2017 and beyond than in 2016. Although this weakness in the spot market has impacted forward markets, we are confident in our fundamental view of the gas and power markets and are positioning our portfolio to take advantage of this.
Now I'll turn it over to Jack to review the full financial information for the quarter.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe, and good morning, everyone. We had another strong quarter. My remarks will cover our financial results for the quarter, third quarter guidance range and our cash outlook.Starting with our second quarter results on Slide 7, Exelon exceede
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe, and good morning, everyone. We had another strong quarter. My remarks will cover our financial results for the quarter, third quarter guidance range and our cash outlook.
Starting with our second quarter results on Slide 7, Exelon exceeded our guidance range and delivered earnings of $0.59 per share. This compares to $0.51 per share for the second quarter of 2014. Exelon's utilities delivered combined earnings of $0.25 per share, and were flat to the second quarter of last year. During the quarter, we saw favorable weather at PECO and an unfavorable weather at ComEd. 
Cooling degree days were up nearly 37% from the prior year and 47.4% above normal in South Eastern Pennsylvania and down 34% from the prior year and 21.6% below normal in northern Illinois. Distribution revenues at ComEd and BGE were higher quarter-over-quarter. In addition, BGE had a decrease in uncollectible accounts expense compared to the second quarter of 2014.
Exelon Generation had another strong quarter, delivering earnings of $0.36 per share, $0.09 higher than the same period last year. As Joe mentioned, our generation to load matching strategy continues to prove effective. We benefited from a lower cost to serve both our retail and wholesales customers and has strong performance from our portfolio management team. In addition, compared to the second quarter of 2014, we had fewer outage days at our nuclear plants, which had a positive contribution from the Integrys acquisition, higher realized nuclear decommissioning trust fund gains and received additional benefits quarter-over-quarter from the cancellation of the DOE's spent nuclear fee. These positive factors were partially offset by higher tax and interest expense. More detail on the quarter-over-quarter drivers for each operating company can be found on Slides 18 and 19 in the appendix.
For the third quarter, we are providing guidance of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. Accounting for the impact of the increased share counts and the debt associated with Pepco Holdings transaction and assuming the transaction closes in the third quarter, we are narrowing our full year guidance from $2.25 to $2.55 per share to $2.35 to $2.55 per share. Our guidance does not assume that bonus depreciation is extended.
Slide 8 provides an update on our cash flow expectations for this year. We've simplified the format of our slide to provide a clearer view of our cash flow at each operating company, including explicitly showing free cash flow. We project cash flow from operations of $6.6 billion. We project free cash flow of $900 million in generation in 2015. 80% of our total growth capital expenditures are being invested in our utilities over the next 3 years, which will provide stable earnings growth. 
In June, we completed the debt portion of our financing for the Pepco transaction by issuing $4.2 billion in senior notes with the majority of these proceeds being used to fund the transaction. Strong market demand allowed us to upsize the offering, enabling us to pull forward some future planned corporate debt issuances. We issued across the tenet [ph] spectrum with an average maturity of approximately 14 years and an average weighted average coupon of 3.79%.
Earlier this month, we completed the settlement of the equity forward transaction. The combination of these financings allows us to close the merger quickly upon receiving approval from the D.C. Public Service Commission. Our balance sheet remains strong and gives us the ability to invest and grow our business. As a reminder, the appendix includes several schedules that will help you in your modeling efforts.
Thank you, and we'll now open the line for questions.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, when you talk about the commercial opportunities in the context of your comfort level raising your guidance for power new business to go, are we talking about sort of the inherent counter cyclicality of the margins in that bu
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, when you talk about the commercial opportunities in the context of your comfort level raising your guidance for power new business to go, are we talking about sort of the inherent counter cyclicality of the margins in that business in the low wholesale environment, i.e., are we moving closer off the $2 floor in margins and closer to the $4, sort of, peak of the cycle margins that you see in that business historically? Or is it simply new customers, more volumes than you had projected in either the gas or the electric business?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joe?
componenttext: Joe?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg. In this specific -- specifically, for 2016 where we're raising our power new business to grow by $50 million and 2017 by $100 million, it's really -- it's not related to those load margins. It's more specifically related to proprietary structur
componenttext: Yes, Greg. In this specific -- specifically, for 2016 where we're raising our power new business to grow by $50 million and 2017 by $100 million, it's really -- it's not related to those load margins. It's more specifically related to proprietary structured commercial opportunities that we have really solid line of sight into on our wholesale side of the business, quite frankly. To your point though, I think it's important to note we have raised our target $50 million each quarter for 2015 for a total of $100 million so far year-to-date and a lot of that has been driven by really 3 things. One is the monetization of loads that result in higher prices last year. So we have seen increased value from that load serving business, some of our optimization activities, and then we went in, as you saw from our disclosures last quarter, we went in with a short bias with the backstop of our own generation and given the results of market prices that in '15 to date, that performed well. We would only look to raise those targets, the power to go target to our non-power to go targets if we have good line of sight into specific opportunities and in this case, we do.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay, a follow-up to that. If these are fairly chunky opportunities and you win them, will we get sort of a discreet disclosure? Or would that just -- will we get -- would you just update it on a quarterly basis as per your usual moving from to go to into the hedges?

componenttext: Yes, yes, yes. We'll disclose that when the negotiations are complete.

componenttext: Okay, great. headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we said, we've got a very good deal on acquiring these assets on our brownfield site, minimal infrastructure investment. They still have a double-digit IRR with these market forwards. If you just projected we stay here for 10 years and then plu
componenttext: Yes. So as we said, we've got a very good deal on acquiring these assets on our brownfield site, minimal infrastructure investment. They still have a double-digit IRR with these market forwards. If you just projected we stay here for 10 years and then plug the fundamentals in after, we're still at a double-digit IRR. This is a solid investment. These are going to be dispatched first, they're highly efficient, air cooled and at the right price.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is just with respect to the power views, I kind of feel like the last few calls you've been a little bit more mixed on your power views. You're a lot more bullish right now, at least, I guess, with respect to NiHub. Is that mainly ju
componenttext: Okay. Second question is just with respect to the power views, I kind of feel like the last few calls you've been a little bit more mixed on your power views. You're a lot more bullish right now, at least, I guess, with respect to NiHub. Is that mainly just the fact that you had to pull back as of Q2 end and so you're just more bullish because the starting price is lower? Or are you more bullish even if prices have stayed flat?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The prices have gone lower, we're more bullish. They're non-sustainable at this level.
componenttext: The prices have gone lower, we're more bullish. They're non-sustainable at this level.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, what I would say is our view of the absolute value of power price hasn't changed quarter-over-quarter. And what's changed is we saw a material drop in the back end of the power curve, and I'm talking to NiHub but it's attributable to West Hub
componenttext: Yes, Steve, what I would say is our view of the absolute value of power price hasn't changed quarter-over-quarter. And what's changed is we saw a material drop in the back end of the power curve, and I'm talking to NiHub but it's attributable to West Hub as well, but our upside is really baked at NiHub where we see material upside as you move out into that '18, '19 time frame. We see upside as well in that '16, '17 period and what's changed is the market has fallen so much quarter-over-quarter. Our absolute view of power price hasn't changed so that spread has gone wider. And when we look at our fundamental models at NiHub, in particular, we see a lot of value that -- to still be derived. And that's due to the changing dispatch back and some of the other things that we've talked about previously.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Talk about the lack of liquidity.
componenttext: Talk about the lack of liquidity.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The liquidity piece of it is a big part of it, Steve. We had a $0.40, approximately $0.40 in megawatt hour drop in PJM and West Hub and NiHub in calendar 2016. That's the most liquid period on the forward curve. When we pull data that we have access
componenttext: Yes. The liquidity piece of it is a big part of it, Steve. We had a $0.40, approximately $0.40 in megawatt hour drop in PJM and West Hub and NiHub in calendar 2016. That's the most liquid period on the forward curve. When we pull data that we have access to and look at what's going on in the out-years, '18, '19, '20, where we saw a material drop in prices, there is absolutely nothing trading at NiHub. There had been some few sporadic trades at West Hub and you see the markets set prices off of those trades and our view is, through time, that spread relationship between West Hub and NiHub is going to collapse because of the retirement from the Western side, the new builds on the Eastern side, and that's why we think there's material upside. But our fundamental absolute view on power price hasn't changed. It's just the way the market reacted quarter-over-quarter.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question will come from the line of Daniel Eggers with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And your next question will come from the line of Daniel Eggers with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: On Pepco, can we just talk about the process, so assuming the D.C. decision comes soon, what is the process for closing from this point? And what bearing does the Maryland appeal have on your ability to close right now?
componenttext: On Pepco, can we just talk about the process, so assuming the D.C. decision comes soon, what is the process for closing from this point? And what bearing does the Maryland appeal have on your ability to close right now?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me get Darryl Bradford to cover that.
componenttext: Let me get Darryl Bradford to cover that.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, we expect to, assuming an acceptable order from the D.C. Commission, we expect to close promptly after that order. Our contract would indicate that, that would take place within 48 hours of approval by the D.C. Commission. And we don't think that the
componenttext: Dan, we expect to, assuming an acceptable order from the D.C. Commission, we expect to close promptly after that order. Our contract would indicate that, that would take place within 48 hours of approval by the D.C. Commission. And we don't think that the Maryland motion should be any bar to us closing. We don't believe that, that motion has any merit whatsoever. As you know, the alleged conflict of interest, one of the commissioners having a preliminary interview and discussion, which she stopped, with a nonparty isn't the basis under Maryland law to question the independence of that decision, let alone to stay the proceedings. No court in Maryland and no commission in Maryland has ever suggested there's a conflict with the commissioner of any agency having a conversation with a nonparty, particularly, whereas here, Exelon is one of some 45 board members, 140 members in an agency that includes public-interest movements like Public Citizen, which was a party below and was the first one to raise this conflict issue. So we don't think that, that motion has any merit. We filed a response yesterday with the court, and we plan to go ahead and close promptly after the D.C. Commission issues an order, assuming that, that order has acceptable conditions and we have faith that the D.C. Commission will do the right thing. We think we've put in a strong case with a lot of benefits for customers and protections for customers. And we look forward to a prompt closing.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then I guess just on the nuclear plants in Illinois. You're with -- your PJM, probably moving the closure date to October, that's still probably before Illinois can act legislatively. With the drop in the forward curves, is there a pract
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then I guess just on the nuclear plants in Illinois. You're with -- your PJM, probably moving the closure date to October, that's still probably before Illinois can act legislatively. With the drop in the forward curves, is there a practical way where you can look at those plants and think that they stay economic without some sort of legislation in Illinois? And does that force your hand come October?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The capacity market fixes, focus on reliability will not be enough to keep all the units economically viable. It does give us some support for the investments that we continue to make on the assets to maintain the reliability but it's not totally there. W
componenttext: The capacity market fixes, focus on reliability will not be enough to keep all the units economically viable. It does give us some support for the investments that we continue to make on the assets to maintain the reliability but it's not totally there. We need a market fix in Illinois to stop the noncompetitive nature of the market. And short of the legislation to fix that, we will have to make decisions on retiring assets that are not economically viable. As we talked about previously, we have requirements around notification to PJM of our intent to retire units, it's an 18-month notification. We also have commitments around when we have to notify of our availability for the '18, '19 auction in participation on that. And very importantly, we have to order and design course that -- due [ph] course to take a while for us to '19, '20 auctions, I said '18, '19 -- '19, '20 auction, our participation there. And we have to order the course. And there's a long lead time there, are we going to run for an additional year, are we going to run for a longer period of time, and that's a very expensive decision to make. So at least on the PJM assets, we'll make the decision if we're going to do that in the September time frame. We've been in consultation with the board and we'll continue to consult with the board. When management has made their decision, we'll pass that to the board for the final approval in that time frame, and continue with outreach to our stakeholders.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, just given the fact that you're not going to have legislation realistically done before September and you've kind, you've laid out the other challenges, doesn't it -- what would cause you to not close the plants come September based on the fact how
componenttext: Chris, just given the fact that you're not going to have legislation realistically done before September and you've kind, you've laid out the other challenges, doesn't it -- what would cause you to not close the plants come September based on the fact how you just laid out for us?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If the units clear the '18, '19 auction, that would show that they're financially viable. That is a long shot, in our opinion, just because of the cost structure and how the forwards have continued to collapse at the bust, at a couple of these units where
componenttext: If the units clear the '18, '19 auction, that would show that they're financially viable. That is a long shot, in our opinion, just because of the cost structure and how the forwards have continued to collapse at the bust, at a couple of these units where we get the transmission constraints, we've got the overproduction and importation of wind that not only drops the spot but continues to collapse the forward curve. The disconnect between NiHub and the bust [ph] at some of these units is $6, $7. And we have worked very closely with all the stakeholders involved for over 1.5 years on trying to come to resolution and it is the time that we'll have to make the decision after we see what happens with the capacity auctions. We don't take the decision lightly. We understand the effect that we have on the communities and potential effect on employees. But this has been a long-term issue that we've been evaluating and trying to come to resolution. And we're staying within the time line actually, we extended our time line last year to give more time to come up with the proper market fixes and to be compensated adequately for operating these units versus subsidizing a low-cost market.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I don't mean to beat this dead horse for this, but would closing a Quad or a Clinton show up noticeably as accretive to you guys on 2017 numbers?
componenttext: And I don't mean to beat this dead horse for this, but would closing a Quad or a Clinton show up noticeably as accretive to you guys on 2017 numbers?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't -- we have not looked at that and don't look at it. We analyze the plants as a stand-alone in their own economics. So it's about a plant losing money, we have not evaluated. Others have, and others have talked about the impact of consumers on tho
componenttext: We don't -- we have not looked at that and don't look at it. We analyze the plants as a stand-alone in their own economics. So it's about a plant losing money, we have not evaluated. Others have, and others have talked about the impact of consumers on those units closing, the state itself did that assessment and there is some material impact on the consumer, but we have not evaluated anything specific to Exelon.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: One, just given your comments about liquidity in the forward curve, is it fair to assume that you've probably not done much in the way of 2018 hedging yet because ordinarily you'd have been a couple of quarters into it, just curious, give us any insight?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Jonathan, we are behind our ratable sales plan in 2018. As you know, we have a very big load serving book of business. So we've captured opportunities both in our retail and wholesale load serving business to the extent possible in 2018. And in addit
componenttext: Yes, Jonathan, we are behind our ratable sales plan in 2018. As you know, we have a very big load serving book of business. So we've captured opportunities both in our retail and wholesale load serving business to the extent possible in 2018. And in addition, at times, we've spoken about in other years, we use the gap market as well. But to sell straight OTC power in 2018, we've not done much, if any, of that at all.

componenttext: Sorry to re-ask that. And then, Chris, at the outset you made the comment that you saw the inclusion of DR in the transition auction as being, I think, you said nonmaterial to the outcome.

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: Can you share a bit more of your, kind of, logic and thought process behind that statement?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe?
componenttext: Yes, Joe?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, it's Joe. First of all, we lost over $1 billion of market cap post the announcement of that, of the inclusion of DR in '16, '17 and '17, '18, and we really thought it was a little bit of an overreaction. As Chris mentioned, we're disappointed in
componenttext: Jonathan, it's Joe. First of all, we lost over $1 billion of market cap post the announcement of that, of the inclusion of DR in '16, '17 and '17, '18, and we really thought it was a little bit of an overreaction. As Chris mentioned, we're disappointed in a way but we don't believe there's going to be a material impact to either those transition auctions. As you're aware, DR was already included in '18, '19 and beyond. The reason we don't think it's a material impact in the transition auction is really related to how the auctions itself cleared on the base residual and the separation in price in '16, '17 on one side, and then the amount of DR that cleared in '17, '18 auction. And when we put that all into our model, it's very similar to what we've read quite frankly from a lot of what's been written by the equity community that it's going to be a limited impact.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question will come from the line of Julien Smith with UBS.
componenttext: And your next question will come from the line of Julien Smith with UBS.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first quick question and it does kind of rehash a little bit here, but on the fundamental upside you're talking about, just to be clear, what does that assume in terms of retirements just to be clear, your own retirements, particularly as you're thinki
componenttext: So first quick question and it does kind of rehash a little bit here, but on the fundamental upside you're talking about, just to be clear, what does that assume in terms of retirements just to be clear, your own retirements, particularly as you're thinking about the life of your portfolio here in the back half of the year?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have not evaluated the potential retirement of any of our assets on market forward prices. And -- so this is just based off of fundamentals of what has been announced and what we see for retirements, what we see for the economic viability of the e
componenttext: Yes, we have not evaluated the potential retirement of any of our assets on market forward prices. And -- so this is just based off of fundamentals of what has been announced and what we see for retirements, what we see for the economic viability of the existing fleet and what they would have to clear to stay viable going forward. So it's not a sustainable market forward with the asset mix that's currently in. It has nothing to do with any forward decision we would make.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So just to be clear, nuclear retirements will be incremental to your fundamental upside?
componenttext: Right. So just to be clear, nuclear retirements will be incremental to your fundamental upside?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't know that. We have not analyzed it, and I wouldn't want to -- I wouldn't want to project one way or the other. It's -- there are 2 different things. The nuclear asset retirement is based off of the economic viability of the asset on the stand-alo
componenttext: We don't know that. We have not analyzed it, and I wouldn't want to -- I wouldn't want to project one way or the other. It's -- there are 2 different things. The nuclear asset retirement is based off of the economic viability of the asset on the stand-alone and we have had losses, in free cash flow losses in the trailing 5 years of some significance. And we project, going forward, with these market forwards, them to even be worse than they were a year ago, which is driving us to make that decision. It is not based off of any potential impact on the market forwards or the rest of the fleet's viability.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then 2 subsequent questions here. First, in terms of the FCF losses, what would you estimate those as being, both for the Eastern portfolio and for the ComEd portfolio as it stands today? And then secondly, tied into that, as you evaluate the
componenttext: Got it. And then 2 subsequent questions here. First, in terms of the FCF losses, what would you estimate those as being, both for the Eastern portfolio and for the ComEd portfolio as it stands today? And then secondly, tied into that, as you evaluate the remaining life of some of these assets, would you imagine layering one announcement after another, so I suppose, specifically there's a timing issue related to ordering new course? I imagine certain units has to get those orders in before others. Can we see one nuclear retirement and then subsequently depending on what happens in the legislative arena, et cetera, see further announcements later this year, in trying to reconcile the bigger issues around FCF deficit?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've discussed, fairly openly the units, the affected units. PJM's rules require us an earlier notification and MISO's rules. And so we would be moving forward, if we have to, on PJM units before MISO units. We don't project a MISO decision until be
componenttext: Yes, we've discussed, fairly openly the units, the affected units. PJM's rules require us an earlier notification and MISO's rules. And so we would be moving forward, if we have to, on PJM units before MISO units. We don't project a MISO decision until beginning of next year looking at the opportunities we have with that unit even through legislation or other mechanisms to secure the required revenues that we need there. We talked about New York units where we're still working with our partners and our stakeholders in New York to look at is there a viable way beyond, our reliability must run situation to maintain economic viability there. And the final asset that's been in discussion is Oyster Creek, which we've already had agreed upon, early retirement dates at the end of 2019. So short of a -- short of some type of failure that was a costly failure on the unit, we would run into that period to allow adequate transition, utilization of the fuel in adequate transition of our employee base to other facilities.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. But just to be clear about the MISO unit there, depending on the success this year in the legislative arena, would that drive that decision?
componenttext: Got it. But just to be clear about the MISO unit there, depending on the success this year in the legislative arena, would that drive that decision?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It would have -- it would heavily weigh our decision.
componenttext: It would have -- it would heavily weigh our decision.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we have time for one final question. Your final question will come from the line of Chris Turnure with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we have time for one final question. Your final question will come from the line of Chris Turnure with JPMorgan.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get a little bit more color on the Pepco approval process here and the core challenge than what you've already talked about. Do you have any sense of the precedent or a precedent for actually staying a commission order? Obviously, you disagree
componenttext: I wanted to get a little bit more color on the Pepco approval process here and the core challenge than what you've already talked about. Do you have any sense of the precedent or a precedent for actually staying a commission order? Obviously, you disagree with the merit of this case, but do you have any precedent there? And what would be the path forward if it was not stayed and you've got the decision out of D.C.?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. It's Darryl again. Yes, the precedent on a stay is very clear in Maryland. It's an extraordinary remedy. It is rarely granted. You have to show a likelihood of success on the merits. And the motion does not, on the merits of the underlying merger,
componenttext: Thanks. It's Darryl again. Yes, the precedent on a stay is very clear in Maryland. It's an extraordinary remedy. It is rarely granted. You have to show a likelihood of success on the merits. And the motion does not, on the merits of the underlying merger, raise any issues whatsoever. The only issue it raises is the suspicious [ph] purported conflict claim, which we think is very, very weak. So we don't think they attempted to meet that. They would also have to show irreparable harm, which they spent a paragraph trying to satisfy that. It's really not very persuasive in our view. They would have to show that it stays in the public interest. And of course, not only has the Maryland commission, but the New Jersey commission, the FERC, the Delaware commission have all found that this merger isn't a public interest and they have also have to show that the hardships favor them and then our pleading we lay out why disrupting the hardship potentially disrupting a $7 billion merger outweighs any hardships that would occur from the grant of the stay. So we think it's an extraordinary remedy. We don't think that they've come close to meeting those standards in any respect and the law is also very clear that in Maryland, it's not a balancing. They have to satisfy each and every one of those elements. And in this case, in our view, they haven't satisfied any of them. So that leaves us in a position where upon D.C. approval and assuming that the court agrees with the pleading we filed yesterday and doesn't grant a stay that promptly upon the D.C. commission joining the other commissions and timing that this isn't a public interest and assuming that any conditions that it imposes are not unduly burdensome, that we would close promptly.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very helpful. And then is there -- or my understanding is that D.C has to rule by the end of August. Is there any flexibility around that timing? Can they extend that again?
componenttext: Great. That's very helpful. And then is there -- or my understanding is that D.C has to rule by the end of August. Is there any flexibility around that timing? Can they extend that again?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There is no clock in D.C. So they are not under any time constraint. Generally, the D.C. commission has ruled within 90 days of something being fully brief and submitted to them. This was fully briefed at the end of May. So that 90 days would end at
componenttext: Yes. There is no clock in D.C. So they are not under any time constraint. Generally, the D.C. commission has ruled within 90 days of something being fully brief and submitted to them. This was fully briefed at the end of May. So that 90 days would end at the end of August. I think that's where that date comes from. Obviously, we're hopeful that sooner is better than later. But that will be up to the D.C. commission and they'll rule when they have finished their work there, I think, acutely aware that a lot of people are looking for a decision from them and they understand that, but they'll take the time that they need necessary in order to do their job right.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then if I could, real quick, Joe, I just wanted to follow up, you've mentioned lack of liquidity in the forward markets a couple of times in the call here. Is this a lack of liquidity that exceeds just the general nature of these markets and what you've seen historically, has that increased? And if that is the case, do you have an opinion as to why there might be so few trades going on out there?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's probably worse than it has been historically. And I think some of it, there's just no natural buyers out that far out on the forward curve. As I said, at the back end of the forward curve we dropped much more than, really, 2016 where the
componenttext: Yes, I think it's probably worse than it has been historically. And I think some of it, there's just no natural buyers out that far out on the forward curve. As I said, at the back end of the forward curve we dropped much more than, really, 2016 where there were more natural buyers whether we talk about retail or speculators here or other participants. So I think, with some of the folks that you saw participating in the markets not doing that, some of the banking side and others, I think, have a material impact.
